text: Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)
Solutions and Strategies
The beginning of the Summary should be a time for students to share their strategies for finding the amount of supplies needed for making juice for 210 campers.

Choose groups of students who used different strategies. Have them explain why they think their ideas make sense and answer the questions. You want students to leave this Problem having experienced several problem-solving strategies and making connections between them.
Suggested Questions
• How are the strategies used in our classroom similar to and different from each other? (Answers will vary.)

Students may use rate tables (like Adia in the What If), equations to scale (like Otis in the What If), or other more unique strategies. One possibility includes drawing pictures to show all of the relationships in the recipe.
• Do you have What If questions? (Answers will vary.)
Making the Mathematics Explicit
Have students analyze and critique Adia’s and Otis’s strategies.
Suggested Questions

• How are Adia’s and Otis’s strategies alike? Different? (Answers will vary. Students may say that Otis shows one pair of equivalent ratios while Adia shows many. Or Otis scales up to 210 cups of juice right away while Adia uses multiples of the two quantities to scale up.)
Make sure that someone points out that looking at Adia’s ratio table, we can see multiple proportions. Some examples are shown below.
To relate the table to the proportions, it is important to have students label the quantities shown by the ratios written in fraction from.
It will be important for students to see how the scaling for the ratio in fraction form can be represented on the ratio table.
Now What Do Students Know
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.
How do the strategies you used in this problem compare to those used in Problem 1.1?
See answers for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.
Reflecting on Student Learning
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?
